My partner never had any testing, but the only reason I don‚Äôt think it is from an infection is just because every time it happens (which is every time I have sex) I never have any other symptoms. Thank you so much for your reply, and I‚Äôll definitely be talking about this next time I go to the gyno :)

Do you think pelvic floor dysfunction could cause someone to not be able to have sex daily? 

By not be able to, I mean that I experience sore and swollen tissues around the vaginal opening even when the sex was completely lubricated (though proper lubrication does help). It sucks to have to take at least a day‚Äôs down time between PIV sex, not to mention the discomfort. 

This started when I was pregnant with my daughter. I realized that it was initially due to an infection (accompanied by other symptoms like itching/burning), but after it was treated, this particular symptom just never went away. It‚Äôs like sex causes inflammation of the tissues in the same way, even though the infection is gone. 

It‚Äôs honestly a bit heartbreaking, because I feel like my tissues are damaged/broken/dysfunctional. Combined with all the other bodily changes from having a baby, it‚Äôs frustrating to say the least. When I was younger, I could participate several times a day, with no pain after.

My husband did this to me. He didn‚Äôt really love me and always put gaming above me, or made me feel so shitty about it every time I begged for more interaction. I didn‚Äôt like it from the beginning, but eventually I came around and supported him and made his little icon art too and then he left me later. 

Now we are separated, and without me doing his share of the childcare, suddenly he only has time to play on weekend late nights like a normal person. 

My point is that some people will use you if you let them, even if they lie to themselves and believe they‚Äôre not. It‚Äôs probably time to tell her you have to go because of this. If she says ‚Äúno, wait I will stop!‚Äù (As in, cut down significantly) Then she really loves you. But if she just lets you go, or tells you not to leave but doesn‚Äôt say she will change, then you‚Äôve gotta go in my opinion.

I‚Äôm no expert but I would guess so. But really they could get it from even one partner so I don‚Äôt know that you ever really know. And there‚Äôs several different types of HPV. 

Personally, it‚Äôs what I‚Äôve witnessed with my aunt, combined with my Ex‚Äôs sex/pornography addiction, that leads me to be perfectly okay with waiting. I want to end up with a man who wants to be with ME, and not think he‚Äôs entitled to sex whenever he feels like, without any regard for the reasons behind why I‚Äôm not feeling it. Because I think that‚Äôs basic human decency!

Not to mention that I could possibly already have it asymptomatically from previous partners. I don‚Äôt honestly know if my gyno tests for all the types. So I‚Äôm just going to act as if I am infected, and keep others safe. 

So hopefully, removing sex from the dating picture will protect others,and guard my heart, my body, and my standards. :)

The reason that we should not do that is because we literally just don‚Äôt have to. The animals kill because they are carnivores. There‚Äôs a small portion of the human population that can‚Äôt live without meat, sure I guess. But for the rest of us, it‚Äôs entirely unnecessary. 
Nature is brutal, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we have to keep that part in our society. We let go of a lot of things that are technically natural. 

Ive been vegan for the better part of a decade now, and I gotta tell you it‚Äôs pretty great. The community part is hard because there‚Äôs a lot of holier than thou stuff (like you‚Äôre eternally damned if you‚Äôre not perfectly vegan in a lot of vegan circles) but overall it‚Äôs one of the best choices I ever made, even just taking me into account. I‚Äôm not some fanatic vegan warrior, I just genuinely enjoy it that much and find it completely sustainable.

I‚Äôm sorry, my wording was confusing. his dads ex is crazy. She plays mind games on the daughter (my ex‚Äôs half sister) all the time.

I‚Äôm sorry, but saying that she will end up hurt under his care is pretty serious, and I completely disagree with that. Nothing I wrote about him indicates that he would physically neglect her. Not everyone is black and white; you can have have someone who is emotionally neglectful, but still won‚Äôt endanger his child‚Äôs life. I don‚Äôt appreciate you trying to spin this as me defending him excessively when you keep defending your very serious statement that I‚Äôve made clear is way off base.
I‚Äôm not sure that evil as we think of it exists. Most instances I can think of have a reasoning behind them

I think he will miss her just enough to see her sometimes. He can go days and doesn‚Äôt mind. He won‚Äôt change his act just from me dropping off, I‚Äôve tried. Sucks. 

But really even when things are good, I still need help. My daughter makes it very hard to get school work done, she‚Äôs at a needy age. I think I have some kind of focusing problem too, which doesn‚Äôt help. But we will get through it. I‚Äôm determined to pull us out of this and be able to stop struggling one day.
I‚Äôm going to start asking that he does that at least when he doesn‚Äôt want to do his part.

I also watch tv when she‚Äôs with me too sometimes. I also do dishes and school work and cooking and cleaning and all sorts of things where I‚Äôm busy. She is safe. No parent has their eyes only on their child every second of every day. Not defending him, but it‚Äôs normal to watch tv even when you have children.  

He may skip out on parenting in little or big ways very often, but if I did, I didn‚Äôt mean to paint him as physically neglectful. I‚Äôve never seen evidence of that at all.

He does want to see her, and most of the time (recently), he sticks with the schedule, but it‚Äôs very often that he doesn‚Äôt and basically tells me to fuck off. I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôd ever want me to just take off with her now. It‚Äôs very confusing because he acts like he loves her, and I believe he does, but he doesn‚Äôt think his responsibility to her correlates in any way to that love. 

I tried just sending her when he wanted before, but then what does anyone get out of that? He gets to feel like a good father for doing less than the bare minimum. My daughter gets to see her dad, but only when he wants. I get some inconsistent childcare I guess? I really NEED his parenting for school and my own mental health, and when I just let him decide when to have her, my needs are not met, and things are not equal at all. Which is fucking shit because she is not just my child. I‚Äôve done more than my share. 

If he didn‚Äôt love her, I‚Äôd just take her and run right off, but he does. I think more than anything he just doesn‚Äôt want me having any say over his life, even though I always make sure we agree. 

It‚Äôs confusing because he seems to love her SO MUCH, but then he does these things. If he was horrible, I wouldn‚Äôt have any problem taking her away. 

I‚Äôm sorry, this response is just word vomit. My brain is shot. Please know that I do intend to go forward and change things, and that your response really got to me. I married a man who ended up being just like my father, even though I thought he was so different. You‚Äôre so so right.

I don‚Äôt doubt emotionally, but physically is a bit of a stretch. Maybe he watches too much tv instead of paying quality attention to her, but I don‚Äôt think he endangers her physically at all. But I agree I shouldn‚Äôt be chasing him. It‚Äôs just hard because I honestly need the help a lot.

Like, I get it, you hate dick and don‚Äôt ever want to be pregnant. But why be an asshole to ME for living MY life and just existing as a pregnant person?

If I were divorced from him, I don‚Äôt know how I could make ends meet. He pays for everything. I have a part time family gig right now but it only pays $400/month. It would likely mean that I‚Äôd have to get a real job, and miss a lot of time with my daughter, which would require childcare which would eat up most of the money I made at my job. 

Don‚Äôt get me wrong, I want to get away from him, and hold him accountable, but I‚Äôm already living in my own apartment that he pays for. I know that I earn more than that through the childcare I provide our daughter, but I don‚Äôt want to mess things up for myself. When I lived on my own before, I barely got by, didn‚Äôt have a daughter to take care of, and didn‚Äôt have college. 

And if he did decide to go the opposite route and get custody of her, that would be the end of my whole world. She is the only thing that matters to me, and the only thing worth spending my time on this earth on. 

I don‚Äôt know what the wisest choice is here. I‚Äôm terrified to make a wrong move, because my successful future and time with my daughter are what‚Äôs on the line.

I would try to make your wig look better, or invest in a better wig. I don‚Äôt hate myself by any means, but I just never could make myself like the look of short hair on me, even though I knew it was objectively flattering. I honestly should have purchased a wig or hair piece in my natural color and learned how to make it look natural. I kick myself for not just doing it sometimes. Now my hair is shoulder length and I just think of all that tine I could‚Äôve spent with this look for a reasonable price and a little easy maintenance.

I don‚Äôt think he was but, I DO think he always had the issues that lead him to turn like this when we came up on marriage though. He had a shitty childhood and his parents made harmful decisions. I remember before marriage, I had never been loved (and I don‚Äôt mean infatuated, he showed me true acts of love and acceptance) like that before and I can always tell when someone‚Äôs not being genuine. I started to subconsciously notice things were going wrong when a close family member of his died. (It‚Äôs been years and he‚Äôs still not the same) Then I became pregnant shortly after, which stressed him out extremely because he was doing okay for his age, but not well enough to provide for a child at that time. Then getting married on top of that. All of this combined with my incredibly dependent pickme mode of thinking (due to abandonment issues, go figure) and me trying to make him perfect really did him in. 

The reason why it hurt so bad is because he really used to be an amazing man (and my best friend) and in his depression he became SUCH a deadbeat and traitor and horrible father for a while. It‚Äôs unfortunate that I had to be the main catalyst for this change in him. It was more pain than I wanted to endure. There‚Äôs so many things that I‚Äôd do differently if I could go back, but ultimately now it‚Äôs on him to get better. Now that the anger has mostly passed, I see us both as damaged products of our upbringing. 

All that being said, I absolutely do believe there are a TON of manipulators out there who do take advantage of marriage as a way to tie women to them so they can basically be abusive assholes. I‚Äôve been with a couple guys like that in my younger years.

TLDR: in my particular situation, my ex was not manipulative like that, it was just unresolved mental issues. BUT I definitely believe most of these cases are manipulative asshole guys.

No problem, thank you for handling is so gracefully. Reading your post and comments, i say it seems that your putting your emotional baggage on her only because it does seem like instead of feeling like hearing this stirred something inside you, it comes off more like you feel ‚Äúshe did this to me, she should know better, and I want her to acknowledge she did bad‚Äù

Specifically, your whole build up of ‚Äòit took a lot for me to ask her this‚Äô is adding a lot of baggage to the situation. I understand that she knows that this was difficult because shes your therapist, but if she just said it neutrally, that really plays no part in it. She did nothing wrong from what I can tell in your post. If you go out on a limb like that, you should accept normal, neutral responses (If it was such a response) and not expect other people to answer for them or accept blame for them. Part of good therapy is modeling healthy interactions, and limiting the tiptoeing. 

You say you recognize that there was no ill will, and that it was just a business decision, and that you just want her to let you talk about it. But then you also question her therapeutic skills for saying something you weren‚Äôt comfortable with, and agonize over your feelings about all of it and what you guess she may feel about you. 

So which is it? Are you upset that she said this, or are you upset that she won‚Äôt talk with you about it? or both? 

If you are still upset that she said this at all, like it seems, I guess I‚Äôm not really understanding why, and why you won‚Äôt let it go. If it only came down to business practices and she meant no ill will and didn‚Äôt say it in any rude way, then what is the problem? What is there to hold onto? I think getting down to the deeper issue here will get you better responses. There‚Äôs several things I could guess, but only you know! 

But regardless, if she won‚Äôt talk to you about it after you‚Äôve asked, try telling her again that you‚Äôd really like to return to it to work through. If she still refuses to talk about it, then you‚Äôve got to make a choice on her. 

Please remember that you are in control of you, and you‚Äôve got this!

I most definitely think you‚Äôre over reacting and it sounds a lot like you‚Äôre putting your emotional baggage on your therapist. 

She told you the facts about the situation, and you are at least somewhat aware that you‚Äôre jumping to all these feelings. So why not let them go? At least until you go back and can ask her to clarify. If at that point she says something that is actually harmful, then you‚Äôll have good reason to be upset. But I‚Äôd bet that if you go back and ask, she will tell you that it‚Äôs just down to business practices. As far as I can find in your post, there‚Äôs not anything there that indicates that she said this in any kind of negative way. 

This isn‚Äôt to say that your feelings aren‚Äôt valid, they are of course. But please don‚Äôt put them on your therapist if she didn‚Äôt do anything wrong. Being totally honest with your clients about how your business works is a respected method of client interaction, because with good therapists, there is no ill will behind the scenes that needs to stay hidden. She‚Äôs only doing what she has to most likely. 
Keep your feelings separated from her. Recognize that you are responsible for them. Observe them. Find the deeper trigger. If, while observing, you find that she actually did mean you harm or acted in a truly harmful way, don‚Äôt ignore that either. I wasn‚Äôt in the room with you, maybe she said it in a mean way or something. 
Then, at your next session, please go over these feelings with her. The feelings of shame and blame and more shame over money, all that. 

This is not really as important as your emotional response here, but I‚Äôll add this anyways; many therapists reserve slots for lower paying clients on purpose, because they believe it is important for everyone to have access to therapy. It is something they want to do. They just literally /can‚Äôt afford/ to take on more than a certain amount of time with lower paying clients. 
There‚Äôs no need to feel shame over being a lower paying client here. Money does not define your worth as a human being, or as a client. If she can‚Äôt take more time with you, then she simply can‚Äôt because of her budget. BUT that doesn‚Äôt mean she doesn‚Äôt want to have the time she‚Äôs already set aside for you. üíñ 

(Ps. As for the disassociating problem, I think you should tell your therapist that you can no longer keep seeing her unless this gets resolved. Or however you feel. I mean idk if that‚Äôs how you actually feel, but it seems unsustainable for you.)

He‚Äôs got many issues, and I don‚Äôt think he truly knows what love is. He thinks that he says he loves her so he does and that‚Äôs enough. He doesn‚Äôt realize that the work and time and effort show love more than anything, and that kids can tell the difference. He‚Äôs stuck in his fog of depression, and it‚Äôs his choice alone if he will push through it. It makes me very sad for my daughter that her dad isn‚Äôt able to love her like I do, but it is what it is. I just try to show her all the love I can. As she gets older I plan on being totally honest with her, because I don‚Äôt want her thinking that her dads actions are what love looks like. Hopefully he gets better though. 

What I‚Äôm trying to say is that being empathetic to my husbands situation (while not enabling or excusing his behavior) helped me a lot.
